elements.content: Three porous Cu­(II) coordination polymers {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K­(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3 n (1), {[Cu5(μ8-L1)2(μ3-OH) 2 (H2O) 5 ]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3 n (2), {[Cu5(μ8-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3 n (3), where KH3L1 and H4L2 are semirigid 3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid and 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid, respectively, were synthesized solvothermally. Their guest-accessible voids are 36%, 59%, and 39% in 1, 2, and 3, respectively. These three porous coordination polymers show high catalytic activities for the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) dyes in aqueous solution. The reaction kinetics follow v = k[H2O2]­[RhB], where k = 0.0260 ± 0.001 L·mol–1·min–1 in the presence of 3, while 1 and 2 follow v = [H2O2]­[RhB]/(1/kK + (1/k)­[H2O2]), where K = 5.0 ± 0.5 M–1, k = 0.057 ± 0.007 min–1 for 1 and K = 4.5 ± 0.5 M–1, k = 0.083 ± 0.009 min–1 for 2 at pH 7.0. All three catalysts show good catalytic activity in pH 4.8–8 and are essentially constant in this pH range while further increases will decrease catalytic activity. Complexes 1 and 3 exhibited good structural stability in the catalytic process with no discernible catalytic activity decrease after three catalytic cycles. Complex 2 is unstable in the catalytic process. MS data show that the slow catalyst 3 degrades RhB into aromatic carboxylate. Faster 1 further degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylate, while fastest 2 not only degrades RhB, but also the catalyst itself. These catalysts not only degrade RhB but also methylene blue, saframine T, and orange II. Azo dye orange II was oxidized into red nitrosobenzene and then degraded nitrisobenzene into colorless species. Complex 1 has the advantage of good catalytic activity, stability, and availability. Along with ease of recovery, it will be useful in practical applications.

elements.content: Three porous coordination polymers were synthesized. Their porosity varies from 36 to 59%. All three can effectively catalytically oxidize organic dyes in the presence of H2O2 in neutral aqueous solution. The reaction kinetics was studied, and the mechanism and products were proposed.

All three can effectively catalytically oxidize organic dyes in the presence of H2O2 in neutral aqueous solution. The reaction kinetics was studied, and the mechanism and products were proposed.

elements.content: In recent years, porous coordination polymers (PCPs), also known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have attracted much attention owing to their potential applications in various fields such as catalysis, luminescence, gas storage and separation, ion exchange, toxic gas removal, topological insulators, and magnetism. To date, rational design and synthesis of PCPs with the expected structure and properties still face many difficulties since organic ligands, metallic ions, solvents, reaction temperature, and counterions, etc., may easily affect the structure of PCPs. The greatest advantage of PCPs over other porous materials is their chemical versatility thanks to their chemical composition of metal cations and organic linkers. Combining appropriate metal cations and organic linkers leads to the formation of open metal sites, which may act as catalyst sites. If some open metal sites can be produced in PCP frameworks together with their wide range of pore sizes, shapes, and dimensionality, these sites will be very useful as solid catalysts with high activity and/or high selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, porous coordination polymers (PCPs), also known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have attracted much attention owing to their potential applications in various fields such as catalysis, luminescence, gas storage and separation, ion exchange, toxic gas removal, topological insulators, and magnetism. To date, rational design and synthesis of PCPs with the expected structure and properties still face many difficulties since organic ligands, metallic ions, solvents, reaction temperature, and counterions, etc., may easily affect the structure of PCPs. The greatest advantage of PCPs over other porous materials is their chemical versatility thanks to their chemical composition of metal cations and organic linkers. Combining appropriate metal cations and organic linkers leads to the formation of open metal sites, which may act as catalyst sites. If some open metal sites can be produced in PCP frameworks together with their wide range of pore sizes, shapes, and dimensionality, these sites will be very useful as solid catalysts with high activity and/or high selectivity.

elements.content: Currently, catalysts are used to eliminate organic compounds or harmful pollutants in green technologies. Organic dyes, especially azo dyes, as raw materials are widely used in solar cells, imaging biological samples, pharmaceuticals, traditional textiles, and other industries. The uncontrolled discharge of azo dyes into the environment is alarming due to their toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic characteristics as well as their transformation products. Catalytic degradation is an effective means of eliminating dyes effluents. Since the discovery of photocatalytic splitting of water on TiO2 electrodes by Honda and Fujishima, traditional semiconductor-based photocatalysis, using semiconductors such as TiO2, WO3, and ZnO, was used to eliminate organic contaminants. Researchers have sought new high-efficiency catalytic materials for environmental protection. PCPs have received much more attention, not only for their intriguing topological variety but also for their potential applications such as a catalyst. However, although many PCP-based catalysts were reported, oxidation kinetics, mechanisms, and possible products remained largely unexplored. In this work, three 3D (superscript 3 indicates 3D) porous coordination polymers, {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K­(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3 n (1), {[Cu5(μ8-L1) 2 (μ3-OH) 2 (H2O)5]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3 n (2), {[Cu5(μ8-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3 n (3), constructed using 3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid and 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid, and copper­(II) ions were reported. Their structures are characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG, XRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Their heterogeneous catalytic oxidation activities toward rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) in the presence of H2O2 were also investigated in aqueous solution. Reaction kinetics, possible mechanism, and products were explored.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent-grade quality, obtained from commercial sources, and were used as received without further purification. C, H, and N analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in 400–4000 cm–1 range. Powder X-ray diffractions were measured at a scanning rate of 5° min–1 on a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGAs) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in air. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Pgeneral TU-1900 spectrometer. ESI mass spectra were performed on a Shimadzu LCMS-2020 instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were of reagent-grade quality, obtained from commercial sources, and were used as received without further purification. C, H, and N analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in 400-4000 cm-1 range. Powder X-ray diffractions were measured at a scanning rate of 5° min-1 on a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGAs) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in air. UV-vis spectra were recorded on a Pgeneral TU-1900 spectrometer. ESI mass spectra were performed on a Shimadzu LCMS-2020 instrument.

elements.content: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (17.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), KH3L1 (16.9 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (6 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The reactor was heated at 80 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Blue prism crystals of were obtained in 55% yield based on KH3L1. Anal. Calcd for C70H98O62N3KCu7 (%): C, 34.46; H, 3.47; N, 1.72. Found: C, 34.48; H, 3.50; N, 1.70. elements.content: Well-shaped single crystals of 1–3 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. Data collections were performed with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their ideal position if possible. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in . The selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table S1, Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Well-shaped single crystals of 1-3 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. Data collections were performed with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full matrix least-squares techniques with SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their ideal position if possible. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in . The selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table S1, Supporting Information.

elements.content: The catalytic activities of these as-synthesized single-crystalline PCPs, namely, 1, 2, and 3, were evaluated by catalysis degradation of RhB, MB, ST, and OII aqueous solution at room temperature. The dyes were dissolved in distilled water. A typical experiment of degradation was carried out as follows: 10 mg of catalyst (1, 2, and 3, respectively) was mixed together with 10 mL of 8 ppm RhB aqueous solution in the presence of 30% H2O2 in a 15 mL glass bottle by shaking in an oscillator continuously for 120 min. The clear solution was transferred to a 1 cm quartz cell to measure UV–vis spectra from 320 to 800 nm on a Pgeneral TU-1900 UV–vis spectrometer (stray light < 0.01%; wavelength accuracy, 0.3 nm) every 15 min within 2 h. Pure water was used as reference in all experiments. Solution without catalyst and solution without H2O2 were also measured as control experiments to estimate degradation of the binary system and possible dye adsorption. The experiments were performed at room temperature, and the pH was adjusted by dropwise addition of 0.1 mol/L muriatic acid or potassium hydroxide as required. Without adjusting pH, all dye solutions have pH ∼ 5.0.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Activity

The catalytic activities of these as-synthesized single-crystalline PCPs, namely, 1, 2, and 3, were evaluated by catalysis degradation of RhB, MB, ST, and OII aqueous solution at room temperature. The dyes were dissolved in distilled water. A typical experiment of degradation was carried out as follows: 10 mg of catalyst (1, 2, and 3, respectively) was mixed together with 10 mL of 8 ppm RhB aqueous solution in the presence of 30% H2O2 in a 15 mL glass bottle by shaking in an oscillator continuously for 120 min. The clear solution was transferred to a 1 cm quartz cell to measure UV-vis spectra from 320 to 800 nm on a Pgeneral TU-1900 UV-vis spectrometer (stray light < 0.01%; wavelength accuracy, 0.3 nm) every 15 min within 2 h. Pure water was used as reference in all experiments. Solution without catalyst and solution without H2O2 were also measured as control experiments to estimate degradation of the binary system and possible dye adsorption. The experiments were performed at room temperature, and the pH was adjusted by dropwise addition of 0.1 mol/L muriatic acid or potassium hydroxide as required. Without adjusting pH, all dye solutions have pH ~ 5.0.

Blue crystals of 1–3 were solvothermally synthesized by the reactions of CuCl2·2H2O with KH3L1 (3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid) ligand or H4L2 (4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid) ligand in well-sealed DMF–H2O mixture except in synthesis of complex 2. The molar ratio of CuCl2·2H2O and KH3L1 was kept in 1:2 in the preparation of 1 and 2. The reaction temperature was changed from 85 °C for 1 to 80 °C for 2. In the synthesis of 3, the metal to ligand ratio was 4:1 and the temperature was 100 °C, which was higher than that in the syntheses of 1 and 2. Although 1 and 2 were synthesized essentially the same, their formulas differ greatly. Subtle change reaction conditions make a great difference. In the sealed vial, there are dimetylammonium cation in 1, which is due to partial decomposition of solvent DMF, while, in the open vial, none of this volatile base exists in 2. Coordinated OH– exists in all three polymers. There are potassium cations in 1, which are proved by precipitation in the presence of tetraphenylboron sodium (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Infrared Spectra

Blue crystals of 1-3 were solvothermally synthesized by the reactions of CuCl2⋅2H2O with KH3L1 (3-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid) ligand or H4L2 (4-(3',5'-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid) ligand in well-sealed DMF-H2O mixture except in synthesis of complex 2. The molar ratio of CuCl2⋅2H2O and KH3L1 was kept in 1:2 in the preparation of 1 and 2. The reaction temperature was changed from 85 °C for 1 to 80 °C for 2. In the synthesis of 3, the metal to ligand ratio was 4:1 and the temperature was 100 °C, which was higher than that in the syntheses of 1 and 2. Although 1 and 2 were synthesized essentially the same, their formulas differ greatly. Subtle change reaction conditions make a great difference. In the sealed vial, there are dimetylammonium cation in 1, which is due to partial decomposition of solvent DMF, while, in the open vial, none of this volatile base exists in 2. Coordinated OH- exists in all three polymers. There are potassium cations in 1, which are proved by precipitation in the presence of tetraphenylboron sodium (Figure S1).

elements.content: These two ligands, L1 and L2, are isomers, and 2 and 3 have quite similar formulas. However, 2 contains more lattice DMF and water molecules, which is mainly due to higher reaction temperature in the synthesis of 3. The IR spectra of complexes 1–3 show characteristic bands of the coordinated carboxylate groups at 1630, 1561; 1625, 1570; and 1617, 1567 cm–1 for CO asymmetric stretching vibrations, respectively (Figure S2). The 1630 cm–1 (in 1) is larger than 1625 cm–1 (in 2) (Figure S2 and ). The absorption bands at 1398, 1399, and 1389 cm–1 are attributed to the symmetric stretching vibrations of the coordinated carboxylate groups for 1–3, respectively. PXRD (Figure S3) proves the phase purity of these polymers.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1 are shown in . The asymmetric unit of {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K­(μ7 -L1)2(μ7 -L1)2(μ2 -OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3 n contains four different metal ions, Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4; one K1; two L14– ligands (in orange and yellow color, a) that both adopt η7μ7–η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination modes (); three coordinating water molecules; and a bridging OH– group (O4W). [(CH3)2NH2]+ exists in the outer sphere to balance the charge. The ligand in orange links six Cu­(II) and a K ion, while the yellow one links seven Cu­(II) ions. The two ligands although both η7μ7 mode, differ in coordination mode (). Cu1 is pentacoordinated by four monodentated carboxyl groups and one coordinated water molecule to form a distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ = 0.21 for Cu1). The equatorial plane is formed by the coordination of O1, O5, O11, and O15 atoms. The axial positions are occupied by O1W atom with an O1W–Cu1–O1 bond angle of 97.9(2)°. The Cu1–O1, Cu1–O5, Cu1–O11, Cu1O15, and Cu1–O1W bond distances are 2.003 (3), 1.925 (3), 1.931(3), 1.998(4), and 2.160(5) Å, respectively. Cu2 is also in a distorted square pyramidal geometry, coordinated by four monodentate carboxyl oxygen and one coordinated water (τ = 0.22 for Cu2). The Cu2–O bond distances vary from 1.932(3) to 2.141(4) Å. Unlike the square paddle-wheel Cu1 and Cu2, Cu3 is quadricoordinated by the monodentating carboxyl group of two L14– ligands and two coordinated water molecules to complete a square planar geometry. The Cu3–O16 and Cu3–O3W bond distances are 1.911(6), 1.937(9) Å, respectively. Cu4 is five-coordinated by four carboxyl oxygens from four different L14– ligands and one μ2-OH anion (O4W), forming a distorted square pyramidal geometry with a τ value of 0.159. The square plane is formed by the coordination of O3, O7, O12, and O4W atoms. The apical positions are occupied by O13 atoms with O7–Cu4–O13 bond angle of 92.89(15)°. The Cu3–O bond distances vary from 1.911(6) to 1.937(9) Å. The dihedral angles between phenyl rings were 77.871°and 79.042° in orange and yellow colored ligand (a), respectively. Cu1 and Cu2 ions are bridged by four L14– ligands to form a propeller-shaped configuration.

The crystal structures of 1 are shown in . The asymmetric unit of {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K(μ7 -L1)2(μ7 -L1)2(μ2 -OH)2(H2O)6]⋅18H2O}3  n  contains four different metal ions, Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4; one K1; two L14- ligands (in orange and yellow color, a) that both adopt η7μ7-η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination modes (); three coordinating water molecules; and a bridging OH- group (O4W). [(CH3)2NH2]+ exists in the outer sphere to balance the charge. The ligand in orange links six Cu(II) and a K ion, while the yellow one links seven Cu(II) ions. The two ligands although both η7μ7 mode, differ in coordination mode (). Cu1 is pentacoordinated by four monodentated carboxyl groups and one coordinated water molecule to form a distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ = 0.21 for Cu1). The equatorial plane is formed by the coordination of O1, O5, O11, and O15 atoms. The axial positions are occupied by O1W atom with an O1W-Cu1-O1 bond angle of 97.9(2)°. The Cu1-O1, Cu1-O5, Cu1-O11, Cu1O15, and Cu1-O1W bond distances are 2.003 (3), 1.925 (3), 1.931(3), 1.998(4), and 2.160(5) Å, respectively. Cu2 is also in a distorted square pyramidal geometry, coordinated by four monodentate carboxyl oxygen and one coordinated water (τ = 0.22 for Cu2). The Cu2-O bond distances vary from 1.932(3) to 2.141(4) Å. Unlike the square paddle-wheel Cu1 and Cu2, Cu3 is quadricoordinated by the monodentating carboxyl group of two L14- ligands and two coordinated water molecules to complete a square planar geometry. The Cu3-O16 and Cu3-O3W bond distances are 1.911(6), 1.937(9) Å, respectively. Cu4 is five-coordinated by four carboxyl oxygens from four different L14- ligands and one μ2-OH anion (O4W), forming a distorted square pyramidal geometry with a τ value of 0.159. The square plane is formed by the coordination of O3, O7, O12, and O4W atoms. The apical positions are occupied by O13 atoms with O7-Cu4-O13 bond angle of 92.89(15)°. The Cu3-O bond distances vary from 1.911(6) to 1.937(9) Å. The dihedral angles between phenyl rings were 77.871°and 79.042° in orange and yellow colored ligand (a), respectively. elements.content: The complex packs into the 3D structure as shown in b,c. For clarity, Cu1Cu2 paddle wheel is a deep-blue ball, 2Cu4 is simplified in yellow balls. Each ligand (O9 andO18) is a four-link node. Cu3 links two ligands; the paddle-wheel Cu1Cu2 (deep blue) links four ligands, while Cu4 dinuclear center (yellow ball) links six ligands. As shown in b, there are cavities in the c-axis. The full structure of the cavity is illustrated in e,f. In the cavity, adjacent Cu3 have distances of 10.40 Å. This distance is comparable with some dye molecules such as rhodamine and so on. Cu3 has lower coordination number, labile water molecules, and guest-accessible voids; this ion may be a catalytic center. Platon calculation shows this complex has a guest-accessible void of 36.5% after removal of lattice water molecule and the dimethylamine.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of six different Cu­(II) ions. L14– ligands adopt a η8μ8–η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode (). All of the carboxylates are in 1,3-bridging modes. Cu3 and Cu4 both have occupancies of 1/4, while the other four Cu­(II) ions have occupancies of 1/2. Three coordinated water molecules (monodentate) and a μ3-OH group (O7W) are also in the inner sphere of complex 2 (a). There are 4.5 DMF molecules and 18 lattice water molecules in the outer sphere. As illustrated in b, Cu2 coordinated with two carboxylates O2 and water oxygen O2W and O7W to form essentially square planar geometry. All other Cu­(II) ions coordinate in square pyramids. Cu1 and Cu2 are linked via O1–C13–O2 (CO2 –) and μ3-OH– to form butterfly Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)4(H2O)4 coordination structures (b).

elements.content: Cu3, Cu4 and Cu5, Cu6 exhibit a propeller-shaped configuration (a). All Cu ions are surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms from four different L14– ligands and one coordinated water molecule. The intermetallic distances between Cu3···Cu4 and Cu5···Cu6 are 2.652(2) and 2.653(2) Å, respectively. While in the μ3-OH (O7W) bridged butterfly structure, Cu···Cu distances are 3.281(3) and 2.977(2) Å for Cu1···Cu2 and Cu1···Cu1, respectively. The Cu2···Cu2 distance is 4.925(3) Å.

elements.content: The carboxylates are almost co-planar to the benzene rings they attached to except the o-carboxylate in the phthalate moiety, which are identical to that in 1. The complex packs into a 3D structure which is illustrated in c,d. For simplicity, the ligand is presented as O9, which is a four-linked node (a). (Cu1Cu2)2 is simplified as large blue balls, which link four ligands as shown in b–d. In the most simplified structure (c, d), not only ligands (O9) but also the paddle-wheel 2Cu centers, as well as the (Cu1Cu2)2, are all four-linked nodes. Interestingly, there are two different cavities in 2. One is a hydrophilic cavity (yellow ball, e) surrounded by eight ligands via the phthalate carboxylate with a cavity diameter of 9 Å (Cu1···Cu1, 9.34 Å; e). The hydrophilic properties arise from the two paddle-wheel Cu3Cu4 and two butterfly Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)4(H2O)4. The other cavity is hydrophobic (blue ball, f). The Cu···Cu distances in the hydrophobic cavity varies from 8.12 to 19.67 Å. The solvent-accessible volume (after removal lattice solvents) is estimated to be 59.3% by PLATON.

elements.content: Complex 3 is quite similar to literature reported {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O} n . Clearly, the formulas differ in lattice DMF and water molecules. The difference between these two complexes is mainly due to reaction temperature. Our synthesizing temperature is 100 °C rather than literature’s 130 °C. The coordination geometry is almost identical except for more accurate bond distances and lower R indices. Due to the existence of DMF and more lattice water molecules, the cell volume is 1280.6(3) Å3, which is 0.79% larger than 1270.95(11) Å3 in {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O} n .

Due to the existence of DMF and more lattice water molecules, the cell volume is 1280.6(3) Å3, which is 0.79% larger than 1270.95(11) Å3 in {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n .

elements.content: The formulas of 3 and 2 are quite similar. Complex 3 differs from 2 in the following aspects: there are only three different Cu­(II) ions rather than six in 2; there is no paddle-wheel dinuclear Cu­(II) in 3; and although there are tetranuclear Cu­(II) clusters, the coordination environment/configuration is different from the tetranuclear cluster in 2. First of all, the tetranuclear clusters in 3 are all five-coordinated (τ = 0.24 and 0.39 for Cu1 and Cu2, respectively) rather than a combination of four and five in 2. The Cu2 ions are trans to each other rather than in the cis butterfly in 2. With a higher number and fewer water molecules, the tetranuclear cluster is linked via six 1,3-coordination carboxylates to form Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6(H2O)2 rather than four 1,3-coordination carboxylates in Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)4(H2O)4 in 2.

elements.content: b is the 3D structure of 3. There are cavities in 3. Platon calculation gives 38.9% voids after removal of lattice solvents, which is considerably less than 59.3% in 2. This can be explained by the larger cell volume of 2, which is 1.4 times the volume of 3. The cavity has a diameter of ∼1 nm. The Cu2···Cu2 distances in the cavity are 12.18 Å. The m-phthalate links different Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6(H2O)2 in the ac plane (a,b), while the o-phthalate links Cu4(μ3-OH)2(CO2)6(H2O)2 and Cu3 in a way shown in d. The Cu3···Cu2 distance is 4.388 Å. The topology view clearly shows that the ligand is a four-link node (c), while the tetranuclear cluster is a six-link node.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of complexes 1–3 were determined in the temperature range of room temperature (RT) ∼ 800 °C (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric curve indicates that 1 released all 24 water molecules and three [(CH3)2NH] in 30–253 °C (found, 20.0%; calcd, 23.1%). The experimental data are 3.1% less than those theoretically calculated, which indicates that 4.23 water molecules were lost before the TGA experiment. The framework then decomposes drastically from 255 to 420 °C. The remaining is 24.4% corresponds to CuO and K2O (calcd, 24.6%). Complex 2 released 23 water molecules and 4.5 DMF in 30–232 °C (found, 37.7%; calcd, 41.8%). Again, 4.05 water molecules volatized before TGA analysis due to very weak binding in the cavity. The 23.9% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 22.3%). For 3, the weight loss of 19.2% could be ascribed to the loss of a free DMF molecule and 14.5 water molecules from 25 to 250 °C (calcd, 24.4%). The 27.3% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 29.0%). The good agreement between theoretical and experimental data indicate all complexes are pure compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stabilities of complexes 1-3 were determined in the temperature range of room temperature (RT) ~ 800 °C (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric curve indicates that 1 released all 24 water molecules and three [(CH3)2NH] in 30-253 °C (found, 20.0%; calcd, 23.1%). The experimental data are 3.1% less than those theoretically calculated, which indicates that 4.23 water molecules were lost before the TGA experiment. The framework then decomposes drastically from 255 to 420 °C. The remaining is 24.4% corresponds to CuO and K2O (calcd, 24.6%). Complex 2 released 23 water molecules and 4.5 DMF in 30-232 °C (found, 37.7%; calcd, 41.8%). Again, 4.05 water molecules volatized before TGA analysis due to very weak binding in the cavity. The 23.9% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 22.3%). For 3, the weight loss of 19.2% could be ascribed to the loss of a free DMF molecule and 14.5 water molecules from 25 to 250 °C (calcd, 24.4%). The 27.3% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 29.0%). The good agreement between theoretical and experimental data indicate all complexes are pure compounds.

elements.content: Organic dyes, especially azo dyes, are ionic, toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic organic compounds which are very stable toward light and oxidation. They are extensively used in industries such as textiles, leather, paper, printing, dyestuff, plastic, and so on. However, organic dyes such as rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue, safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) are some of the largest sources of industrial pollutants. Dumping of these compounds leads to algae propagation and eutrophication in bodies of water, and their extensive application generates considerable amounts of wastewater that poses a serious environmental threat. Furthermore, in consideration of their relatively high chemical stability in aqueous solution, removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater is a challenging task to scientists.

Catalytic Activity

Organic dyes, especially azo dyes, are ionic, toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic organic compounds which are very stable toward light and oxidation. They are extensively used in industries such as textiles, leather, paper, printing, dyestuff, plastic, and so on. However, organic dyes such as rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue, safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) are some of the largest sources of industrial pollutants. Dumping of these compounds leads to algae propagation and eutrophication in bodies of water, and their extensive application generates considerable amounts of wastewater that poses a serious environmental threat. Furthermore, in consideration of their relatively high chemical stability in aqueous solution, removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater is a challenging task to scientists.

elements.content: Recently, PCPs were used for degradation of dyes aqueous solutions. The presence of metal clusters consisting of unsaturated coordination sites or loosely bound solvents are often considered as the criterion of a potential catalyst, and the presence of a cavity inside the network further enhances the possibility of catalytic activity. In the present scenario, 1–3 with different cavities and Cu­(II) centers with vacant coordination sites and/or loosely bound water molecules offer a broad scope of study of catalysis. All three compounds have cavities with a cavity size of ∼1 nm and are expected to have some catalytic oxidation activity. The catalytic activities of 1–3 were examined by the degradation of dye in aqueous solution at room temperature (). We chose RhB as a representative to investigate the degradation process in detail (). Rhodamine B is one of the more important xanthene dyes. It is a common organic pollutant that exhibits considerably high resistance to photodegradation and oxidative degradation.

Effect of Dye Concentration

Before we investigate catalytic oxidation in the presence of H2O2, which is a catalyst-H2O2-dye ternary system, possible reaction in binary systems was run as control experiments. RhB itself is a commonly used dye that is quite stable and difficult to degrade. In the presence of 0.32 M H2O2, 8.0 ppm RhB is also quite stable in pH 4.8-8 (Figure S5). In pH = 9, the degradation cannot be neglected. Without H2O2, there is no fading within 3 h in the presence of 1, 2, or 3 (Figure S6), which indicates that there is no encapsulation. These phenomena indicate that the color fading is exclusively due to catalytic oxidation.

elements.content: In the experimental condition, H2O2 is in large excess and therefore its concentration is expected to remain constant during the whole process. The reaction kinetic can be expressed as v = k[H2O2] n [dye] m = k obs[dye] m , where k obs = k[H2O2] n . Plot of – ln­(A t /A 0) (where A t and A 0 are the 553 nm absorbance at times t and 0) vs time gives a straight line ( inset). This indicates that the degradation reaction is first order to RhB concentration. The observed first-order rate constants (k obs) are 0.032 ± 0.001, 0.040 ± 0.003, and 0.0150 ± 0.0003 min–1 for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. Complexes 1 and 2 have better catalytic activity than that of 3. The half-life times are 30, 25, and 60 min respectively in the presence of 1, 2, and 3. In addition, it is worth mentioning that the degradation spectra are similar between 1 and 2, but different from 3 as the ∼400 nm absorbance differs greatly. This is a hint that they may have different mechanisms/products.

The intercept a = 1/k, the slope b = 1/kK, and K = a/b.

This mechanism is similar to homogeneous degradation of orange II dye in the presence of H2O2 at pH 7 catalyzed by Fe­(III) complexes of tetraamido macrocyclic ligand (K = k 1/k –1 in the pre-equilibrium step). Our rate k (0.083 min–1, or 1.4 × 10–3 s–1) is comparable with reported rates for the homogeneous Fe­(III) catalyst, whose k is (0.5–3) × 10–3 s–1. The pre-equilibrium constant is quite low in our system. It is reasonable to assume that RhB–H2O2 adducts are not very stable. The pre-equilibrium K was unreasonably large for the reported systems due to their k 1 = ∼100 M–1 s–1, while k –1 ≈ 0. However, the comparatively larger Fe­(III)–H2O2 binding constant is reasonable.

elements.content: The pH of the solution also plays an important role in the catalytic degradation. The RhB degradations at pH 4.8, 8.0, and 9.0 are shown in Figures S11, S12, and S13, respectively. The RhB degradation percentage with time at different pH in the presence of 1 is shown in . The degradation profiles for 1, 2, and 3 at pH 4.8, 7.0, 8.0, and 9.0 are shown in Figure S14a–d. For comparison, catalytic degradation percentages of a particular catalyst at different pH were shown in Figure S15. From Figure S14, the degradation efficiency (C t /C 0 = A t /A 0) is in the order 2 > 1 > 3 in pH 4.8–9. From , the catalytic degradation is essentially constant in pH 4.8–8 for complex 1. In this pH range, RhB self-degradation (without catalyst) is negligible. The degradation is attributed to catalytic oxidation. In pH 9, RhB self-degradation is significantly increased while catalytic oxidation is insignificant. These phenomena can be explained by, at pH 9, the activation site of Cu­(II) being occupied by OH–, which is much more difficult to replace by guest molecule H2O2. The difference in the absence and presence of catalyst in pH 9 decreased significantly. The half-degradation time in pH 4.8–8 is estimated to be about 30 min. The RhB degradation over 80% within an hour for complex 1, which is faster than literature data (Tables S2–S5). Complexes 2 and 3 are somewhat similar to that of 1, but the degradation is obviously slower at pH 8 compared to those at pH 4.8–7.0 (Figure S15). The observed first-order rate constants at 0.32 M H2O2 are listed in . Most studies relate to photocatalytic degradation with half-life times of 30–60 min in the presence of 30% H2O2. Our system can degrade RhB in the dark; it has an obvious advantage over photodegradation.

Mass spectrometry (MS) is an effective method to identify products of RhB degradation in solution. It is commonly known that the reaction product highly depends on time. In the oxidation process, catalyst 2 is the most effective as seen from . In the presence of 1, 2, and 3, 8.0 ppm RhB has half-lives of ∼30, ∼25, and ∼60 min, respectively, in pH 4.8–8.0. After 4 h, catalyst 2 has obviously been lost possibly due to oxidation/degradation of ligands. Complex 2 completely disappeared overnight in the catalytic oxidation process, while 1 and 3 have insignificant losses. Complexes 1 and 3 will be completely lost in 3 days. The catalyst degradation, especially compound 2, may be due to its large cavity (59%) making 2 unstable. As a common sense, except kinetically inert Cr­(III) and Zr­(IV) polymers, most other porous coordination polymers are not sufficiently stable in aqueous solution, especially large porous polymers. Our experiments further prove this phenomenon.

Reaction Products

Mass spectrometry (MS) is an effective method to identify products of RhB degradation in solution. It is commonly known that the reaction product highly depends on time. In the oxidation process, catalyst 2 is the most effective as seen from . In the presence of 1, 2, and 3, 8.0 ppm RhB has half-lives of ~30, ~25, and ~60 min, respectively, in pH 4.8-8.0. After 4 h, catalyst 2 has obviously been lost possibly due to oxidation/degradation of ligands. Complex 2 completely disappeared overnight in the catalytic oxidation process, while 1 and 3 have insignificant losses. Complexes 1 and 3 will be completely lost in 3 days. The catalyst degradation, especially compound 2, may be due to its large cavity (59%) making 2 unstable. As a common sense, except kinetically inert Cr(III) and Zr(IV) polymers, most other porous coordination polymers are not sufficiently stable in aqueous solution, especially large porous polymers. Our experiments further prove this phenomenon.

elements.content: The MS spectra were run after 6 h reaction. Their MS spectra were shown in . No RhB can be found in the MS spectra in all three experiments as there is no sign in 443.2 (M+ of free RhB), 399.2 (M+ – C3H8), and 355.1 (M+ – 2C3H8). Possible products were assigned, which are shown in (better than 0.1 mass difference). The catalytic degradation products within 6 h are all due to the RhB in the presence of 1. The degradation product at m/z 104, 145, 230, and 310 are all degradation products of RhB (a). In the presence of 2, however, losses are mainly due to the degradation of ligands in complex (b). This agrees well with the experimental phenomena. In the MS spectra, the ligand is hydrolyzed into hydroxyl phthalate or degraded into biphenyl tetracarboxylate (b).

elements.content: The m/z 347.18 peak in c is quite similar to the ligand peak at 347.04, but the error 0.14 is far larger than any other designation. We designated this peak to an RhB degradation product (c). Clearly, the 183.6 peak can only be assigned to +2 cation of two nitrogen containing species. No ligand degradation product can be found. The degradation product in the presence of 3 is somewhat similar to that of 1 as they are all RhB degradation products. However, the RhB degradation product in the presence of 3 is different from that of 1 as there are no aliphatic dicarboxylates in the presence of 3. The reason is that the degradation of RhB is always from the 2-position of the benzoic acid to form an aromatic carboxylate. Further degradation of aromatic acid forms aliphatic acid. The reaction is much faster in the presence of 1 than in the presence of 3 (); thus RhB degradation is much deeper in the presence of 1. Further degradation may generate CO2 or other smaller compounds through mineralization, which is not a focus in this study.

Further degradation may generate CO2 or other smaller compounds through mineralization, which is not a focus in this study.

elements.content: From the MS data, the products are mainly carboxylate, which can also act as ligand coordination to Cu­(II) ions, especially in higher concentrations. This is the reason why catalysts were lost in extended contact with the solution. These MS results agree well with the reaction kinetics. That is, 3 is the slowest catalyst; it can degrade RhB into aromatic carboxylate, the first stage of RhB degradation. Complex 1 is faster than 3; it degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylate (second degradation stage). The fastest 2 degrades not only RhB but also 2 itself. In summary, 1 showed the best performance not only with higher reaction rate constant but also with the ability of quickly degrading dyes into smaller species by breaking aromatic rings. Although 2 is the fastest, it is unstable in the oxidation process.

elements.content: RhB can be oxidized not only in the presence of 1, 2, and 3 but also in other ways. Figures S16–S18 show spectral changes of 8.0 ppm methylene blue in the presence of 1–3 at neutral pH. Safranine T (cation dye, 24 ppm) and orange II (anion dye, 24 ppm) spectra are shown in Figures S19–S21 and S22–S23, respectively. Similar to the degradation of RhB, these dyes can also be oxidized into colorless products. An 8.0 ppm amount of MB has half-life times of 10, 15, and 40 min in the presence of 2, 1, and 3, respectively (Figure S18), which is faster than that of RhB oxidation. A 24 ppm amount of safranine T (Figure S21) has almost an identical half-life to that of 8 ppm MB. Note that in the oxidation of orange II, the color quickly changes from orange (484 nm) to red (522 nm) within 10 min, followed by the decomposition of 522 nm compounds. The half-time of the 522 nm species is 40, 20, and 65 min in the presence of 1, 2, and 3, respectively (Figure S23). Natural diatomites as a green catalyst for Fenton-like oxidation of orange II in the presence of H2O2 was studied. Its half-life is several hours at room temperature. Graphene base cathode can also degrade orange II via Fenton reaction in the presence of H2O2. This 522 nm species has not been mentioned elsewhere. Orange II has peaks at 484 nm in acidic to pH 11 (Figure S24). Only in a strong basic solution does the orange color at 484 nm split into two peaks at 450 and 520 nm (Figure S24). In our experiments, the solution is neutral or slightly acidic. The 522 nm peak is not the dianion dye as their shapes differ greatly (no 450 nm peak in the presence of our complexes). Previously, in attempts to synthesize MOF with azo ligands, azo was oxidized into nitrosobenzenes XC6H4N­(O):N­(O)­C6H4X or XC6H4N­(O):NC6H4X (X is carboxylate) in air atmosphere. Sakaue et al. reported that the oxidized products of various substituted anilines XC6H4NH2 were selectively converted into the corresponding nitrosobenzenes XC6H4N­(O):N­(O)­C6H4X (II) or nitrobenzenes XC6H4NO2 (Xs are substituents) by oxidation with aqueous hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by heteropolyoxometalates. The homogeneous catalytic activity of the N-tailed tetraamido macrocyclic Fe­(IIII) activators in the oxidative bleaching of orange II dye by H2O2 in aqueous solution was studied; it was found that Fe­(III) complexes have the best catalytic activity at pH 10.5, but there is no peak at 522 nm. We attribute this 522 nm peak to the oxo-azo orange II, possibly due to the cavity favoring oxygenation of the azo group. This phenomenon has resulted in an azo compound (but not the orange II) in the presence of strong oxidant.

elements.content: The reusability of complexes 1–3 was evaluated by 8.0 ppm RhB degradation in the presence of H2O2 at pH 4.8. After each experiment (1.5 and 2 h for 1 and 3, respectively), the catalyst was separated by filtration and used without further treatment. Noticeably, the catalyst did not exhibit significant loss of catalytic activity and the degradation efficiency was still higher than 88% after three recycles for 1 and 3. To confirm the stability of the catalysts, we compared IR and PXRD before and after catalysis. The IR pattern of each compound was similar to those of the fresh compound (Figure S25). After catalysis, a new peak at 1732 cm–1 appeared, possibly because some carboxylic acid molecules (degradation product) contaminated/were adsorbed in the cavity of 1. For 2 and 3, there is no sign of IR change before and after catalysis. The PXRD patterns of 1 and 3 are identical before and after catalysis (Figure S26a,c). However, for 2, the PXRD pattern changes obviously before and after catalysis (Figure S26b). This may explain why 2 dissolves in the catalytic process. Our results demonstrated that 1 and 3 may be reusable for the catalytic reduction of toxic organic dyes and for purifying of wastewater.
elements.clean_text:
Stability and Reusability of Catalysts

The reusability of complexes 1-3 was evaluated by 8.0 ppm RhB degradation in the presence of H2O2 at pH 4.8. After each experiment (1.5 and 2 h for 1 and 3, respectively), the catalyst was separated by filtration and used without further treatment. Noticeably, the catalyst did not exhibit significant loss of catalytic activity and the degradation efficiency was still higher than 88% after three recycles for 1 and 3. To confirm the stability of the catalysts, we compared IR and PXRD before and after catalysis. The IR pattern of each compound was similar to those of the fresh compound (Figure S25). After catalysis, a new peak at 1732 cm-1 appeared, possibly because some carboxylic acid molecules (degradation product) contaminated/were adsorbed in the cavity of 1. For 2 and 3, there is no sign of IR change before and after catalysis. The PXRD patterns of 1 and 3 are identical before and after catalysis (Figure S26a,c). However, for 2, the PXRD pattern changes obviously before and after catalysis (Figure S26b). This may explain why 2 dissolves in the catalytic process. Our results demonstrated that 1 and 3 may be reusable for the catalytic reduction of toxic organic dyes and for purifying of wastewater.

elements.content: In summary, three porous Cu­(II) coordination polymers were synthesized through the solvothermal method. These three porous coordination polymers show high catalytic activities for degradation of dyes aqueous solution, such as rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) without light irradiation. Reaction kinetics and possible product were studied in detail. The reaction kinetics is first order to [RhB] and [H2O2] in low concentration. The rate of catalyst degradation is in the order of 2 > 1 > 3. However, 2 with a cavity of 59% is unstable in the oxidation process. The reaction rates are essentially constant in pH 4.8–8. Further increases in pH will greatly decrease catalytic activity. Within 6 h, slowest 3 degrades RhB into aromatic carboxylates and 2 degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylates, while fastest 2 degrades RhB and itself. Both 1 and 3 can be reused at least 3 times without decreases in catalytic activity. These porous coordination polymers can also catalyze the oxidation of methylene blue, saframine T, and orange II as well. Based on the excellent catalytic activity and stability, 1 and 3 have great potential to be a green catalyst for heterogeneous degradation of hazardous dyes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, three porous Cu(II) coordination polymers were synthesized through the solvothermal method. These three porous coordination polymers show high catalytic activities for degradation of dyes aqueous solution, such as rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) without light irradiation. Reaction kinetics and possible product were studied in detail. The reaction kinetics is first order to [RhB] and [H2O2] in low concentration. The rate of catalyst degradation is in the order of 2 > 1 > 3. However, 2 with a cavity of 59% is unstable in the oxidation process. The reaction rates are essentially constant in pH 4.8-8. Further increases in pH will greatly decrease catalytic activity. Within 6 h, slowest 3 degrades RhB into aromatic carboxylates and 2 degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylates, while fastest 2 degrades RhB and itself. Both 1 and 3 can be reused at least 3 times without decreases in catalytic activity. These porous coordination polymers can also catalyze the oxidation of methylene blue, saframine T, and orange II as well. Based on the excellent catalytic activity and stability, 1 and 3 have great potential to be a green catalyst for heterogeneous degradation of hazardous dyes.

cln_elements.content:
Three porous Cu­(II) coordination polymers {[(CH3)2NH2]3[Cu7K­(μ7-L1)2(μ7-L1)2(μ2-OH)2(H2O)6]·18H2O}3 n (1), {[Cu5(μ8-L1)2(μ3-OH) 2 (H2O) 5 ]·4.5DMF·18H2O}3 n (2), {[Cu5(μ8-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·DMF·10.5H2O}3 n (3), where KH3L1 and H4L2 are semirigid 3-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid and 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid, respectively, were synthesized solvothermally. Their guest-accessible voids are 36%, 59%, and 39% in 1, 2, and 3, respectively. These three porous coordination polymers show high catalytic activities for the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), safranine T (ST), and orange II (OII) dyes in aqueous solution. The reaction kinetics follow v = k[H2O2]­[RhB], where k = 0.0260 ± 0.001 L·mol–1·min–1 in the presence of 3, while 1 and 2 follow v = [H2O2]­[RhB]/(1/kK + (1/k)­[H2O2]), where K = 5.0 ± 0.5 M–1, k = 0.057 ± 0.007 min–1 for 1 and K = 4.5 ± 0.5 M–1, k = 0.083 ± 0.009 min–1 for 2 at pH 7.0. All three catalysts show good catalytic activity in pH 4.8–8 and are essentially constant in this pH range while further increases will decrease catalytic activity. Complexes 1 and 3 exhibited good structural stability in the catalytic process with no discernible catalytic activity decrease after three catalytic cycles. Complex 2 is unstable in the catalytic process. MS data show that the slow catalyst 3 degrades RhB into aromatic carboxylate. Faster 1 further degrades RhB into aromatic and aliphatic carboxylate, while fastest 2 not only degrades RhB, but also the catalyst itself. These catalysts not only degrade RhB but also methylene blue, saframine T, and orange II. Azo dye orange II was oxidized into red nitrosobenzene and then degraded nitrisobenzene into colorless species. Complex 1 has the advantage of good catalytic activity, stability, and availability. Along with ease of recovery, it will be useful in practical applications.

Structure of {[Cu<sub>5</sub>(μ<sup>7</sup>-L2)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sup>3</sup>-OH)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]·DMF·10.5H<sub>2</sub>O}<sup>3</sup> <sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 is quite similar to literature reported {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O} n . Clearly, the formulas differ in lattice DMF and water molecules. The difference between these two complexes is mainly due to reaction temperature. Our synthesizing temperature is 100 °C rather than literature’s 130 °C. The coordination geometry is almost identical except for more accurate bond distances and lower R indices. Due to the existence of DMF and more lattice water molecules, the cell volume is 1280.6(3) Å3, which is 0.79% larger than 1270.95(11) Å3 in {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]·2H2O} n .

Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stabilities of complexes 1–3 were determined in the temperature range of room temperature (RT) ∼ 800 °C (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric curve indicates that 1 released all 24 water molecules and three [(CH3)2NH] in 30–253 °C (found, 20.0%; calcd, 23.1%). The experimental data are 3.1% less than those theoretically calculated, which indicates that 4.23 water molecules were lost before the TGA experiment. The framework then decomposes drastically from 255 to 420 °C. The remaining is 24.4% corresponds to CuO and K2O (calcd, 24.6%). Complex 2 released 23 water molecules and 4.5 DMF in 30–232 °C (found, 37.7%; calcd, 41.8%). Again, 4.05 water molecules volatized before TGA analysis due to very weak binding in the cavity. The 23.9% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 22.3%). For 3, the weight loss of 19.2% could be ascribed to the loss of a free DMF molecule and 14.5 water molecules from 25 to 250 °C (calcd, 24.4%). The 27.3% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 29.0%). The good agreement between theoretical and experimental data indicate all complexes are pure compounds.

Azo dye orange II was oxidized into red nitrosobenzene and then degraded nitrisobenzene into colorless species. Complex 1 has the advantage of good catalytic activity, stability, and availability. Along with ease of recovery, it will be useful in practical applications.

Structure of {[Cu5(μ7-L2)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]⋅DMF⋅10.5H2O}3  n  (3)

Complex 3 is quite similar to literature reported {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n . Clearly, the formulas differ in lattice DMF and water molecules. The difference between these two complexes is mainly due to reaction temperature. Our synthesizing temperature is 100 °C rather than literature's 130 °C. The coordination geometry is almost identical except for more accurate bond distances and lower R indices. Due to the existence of DMF and more lattice water molecules, the cell volume is 1280.6(3) Å3, which is 0.79% larger than 1270.95(11) Å3 in {[Cu5(L1)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n .

Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stabilities of complexes 1-3 were determined in the temperature range of room temperature (RT) ~ 800 °C (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric curve indicates that 1 released all 24 water molecules and three [(CH3)2NH] in 30-253 °C (found, 20.0%; calcd, 23.1%). The experimental data are 3.1% less than those theoretically calculated, which indicates that 4.23 water molecules were lost before the TGA experiment. The framework then decomposes drastically from 255 to 420 °C. The remaining is 24.4% corresponds to CuO and K2O (calcd, 24.6%). Complex 2 released 23 water molecules and 4.5 DMF in 30-232 °C (found, 37.7%; calcd, 41.8%). Again, 4.05 water molecules volatized before TGA analysis due to very weak binding in the cavity. The 23.9% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 22.3%). For 3, the weight loss of 19.2% could be ascribed to the loss of a free DMF molecule and 14.5 water molecules from 25 to 250 °C (calcd, 24.4%). The 27.3% remainder is mainly CuO (calcd, 29.0%). The good agreement between theoretical and experimental data indicate all complexes are pure compounds.

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of 1. Two ligands are in orange and yellow bonds, respectively. Dotted lines are the most simplified coordination mode of the ligands. Large yellow balls are Cu3Cu4; deep-blue balls are Cu1Cu2. Both ligands are four-link nodes. (b and c) Views of the 3D framework along the c-axis and b-axis, respectively. Ligands were simplified as red and purple bonds, respectively. O9 and O18 ligands are both four-linked nodes. Blue and yellow balls are both 2Cu, also four-linked nodes. (d) Linkage of the two ligands. Black balls represent benzene rings. Two red ligands linked via Cu3 (purple bond). (e) 3D view of the complex in the c-axis. (f) Cavity structure in the c-axis. Guest-accessible void is 36%.
